name: Tillicum Creek
description:
A tributary of the Lewis River on the north-northwest side of Indian Heaven. The uppermost drop is Little Niagara which is one of the most photogenic waterfalls in Gifford Pinchot National Forest. Despite being located out in the middle of nowhere, this falls is frequently visited by enthusiastic waterfall photographers. Tillicum Creek drains a good part of the northern end of the Indian Heaven plateau, so it sees good flow well into late summer.

Options:

  • Descend R1 & R2 and exit for a short outing. Requires just a few hours.
  • Full descent - expect it to take most of a day.
  • The bridge just upstream of the parking area may be a good checkpoint for the flow.

Approach

Check Gifford Pinchot NF website for road conditions. As of Aug 2017, FR88 is completely washed out / not passable near Jct 3022.

Facing south from the parking area, look on your right for a flagged user-trail that leads right down to the top of the falls. This is the fastest and easiest route. Trail is a little indistinct in a couple areas near the bottom. Approach: 2min.

  • It's also possible to stream-walk down from the bridge. Some nice bedrock, but otherwise doesn't buy you anything.

Descent

Upper Tillicum

  • R1: Little Niagara Falls - 100ft. DCL on tree. More rope may be required depending on where your anchor is. Please do not leave anchors atop this falls as it's frequently visited by tourists. Use a retrievable or return to the top of the falls at the end of the day to remove your anchor. Leaving anchors may encourage the inexperienced / unprepared to try to follow you. Hugely photogenic falls; see cover photo.

Escape is possible from below R1 by thrashing steeply up and out DCR. Head downstream a hundred yards to R2.

  • R2: Tillicum Falls - 40ft. Anchored off a fallen log DCR. Log is part of a big logjam atop the falls. Rap line will keep you mostly out of the flow. There is a nice grotto below the falls. Walk down another 100ft where a minor tributary ("Lower Tillicum Creek") enters DCL. There is a 20ft low-flow falls visible just upstream.

It is possible to exit below R2 (see "Exit" below).

Lower Tillicum

Otherwise, continue 0.5mi downstream.

  • R3: 50ft from tree DCR. This is in the flow and quite pushy.
  • R4: 80ft from nice set of roots DCR at the top of the second tier.

Continue 0.45mi downstream.

  • R5 KeyHole Falls - 50 ft. DCL off of a tree above the mini-zen pocket. Rappel is just out of the flow.

Continue 0.25mi downstream.

  • R6 Tempest Falls- 85 ft into a nice, deep pool. DCR off of a tree. This drop is especially nice.

Exit

From Below R2

Head downstream a few hundred yards from Tillicum Falls. Duck under two huge old-growth trees spanning the creek exit DCR up into a small area of open forest. Just to climber's left a steep tributary enters. Look for a faint unmarked user trail that heads steeply upwards on the climber's right side of the tributary with one or two scramble moves. The route stays in relatively open forest with a bare minimum of bushwhacking. After about 3-5min you'll run right into an old hiking trail that runs along the north side of Tillicum Creek. Follow the trail to your right through some nice old growth trees. The trail leads right back up to the parking area. The trail comes in right at the north side of the parking area. The trail may be hard to spot from the parking area, but is pretty solid.

Full Descent

Go downstream about 100ft and exit DCR up to an old road that connects to FR 321. This road will take you to FR 32 and back to the trailhead. A shuttle would save an hour walking the 3mi back to your car.

Red tape

None.

Beta sites

NW Waterfall Survey - Little Niagara Falls

Trip reports and media

Video (Oct 2023): https://youtu.be/S52ja-45Y8g

Background

First descent of the top two falls 8/13/17: Keith Campbell, Kevin Clark, Kaitlin Rupert, Kendra Kallevig-Childers, Joe Kellett, and Mark Meyer. First Full descent 8/11/18: Ryan Ernst and Haruka James Clay Lipscomb
